title: Getting Started in Security with BHIS and MITRE ATT&CK w/ John Strand - Antisyphon

last_post.content:
Hey all,

We have heard a lot about the skills gap in security. We are also seeing articles that say we are short something like a million people worldwide.

Because of this we started the Pay What You Can model for intro classes at Antisyphon over COVID.

My next class starts next week.

It is an Intro To Security class.

Yes, even paying nothing is an option.

We do this to help the industry, but more so to help people get jobs that would be unavailable to them.

Any barrier you see can be boiled down to two things. Restrictions on money and restrictions on education. Knowledge is power. But traditionally knowledge was expensive.

Very expensive.

By embracing the Pay What You Can model we at Antisyphon are helping to break down barriers based on where you come from or who you are.

We just want more cool people to do cool stuff with.

Please share this post or link with someone you think would kick ass in the industry, but they just need a shot.

Thanks,

John

https://www.antisyphontraining.com/getting-started-in-security-with-bhis-and-mitre-attck-w-john-strand/

@phessler @daniel @elk I'd like to deescalate this exchange if I can... I have no "dog" in this fight, I just want correct information.

I have independently verified elk.zone's claims that there is no "bsd[.]network" information whatsoever being served by elk.zone itself. I did this by examining the requests my browser made and examining each response's contents.

I tested and confirmed that it is "mas[.]to" providing the content that is displayed. By blocking "mas[.]to" on my local machine (a simple /etc/hosts entry), your information disappears from the Mastodon client (screenshot attached).

If I search "@phessler" on https://mas[.]to and then click on the @phessler@bsd[.]network profile (it's the first of 2 results), it's served from mas[.]to instead of being redirected directly to bsd[.]network (screenshot attached)

If you'd like, this is the the API URL that elk.zone is fetching when loading your profile: https://mas[.]to/api/v1/accounts/lookup?acct=phessler%40bsd.network
Any unauthenticated user agent can HTTP GET that URI and receive details about your account.
That specific Mastodon API endpoint is https://docs.joinmastodon.org/methods/accounts/#lookup

Mastodon instances even cache and serve your media content: https://media[.]mas[.]to/masto-public/accounts/avatars/000/003/067/original/bf5b3817cfcb5c38.png

I understand you do not want to be indexed or crawled. That genuinely does not appear to be the case her -- except for the bit about Google which @pamela discussed, and apparently a PR was deployed promptly. This really appears to be a matter of "the client is displaying the information returned by the server" and nothing more.

Given that the invention of attack trees is commonly attributed to Schneier's 1999 article, I was surprised to see the idea described in a 1991 paper by J.D. Weiss of Bell Labs [1].
Even more surprising is that I found it because it was cited in another paper co-authored by Schneier in 1998 [2].

[1]J.D. Weiss, "A System Security Engineering Process," Proceedings of the 14th National
Computer Security Conference, 1991.
https://csrc.nist.gov/CSRC/media/Publications/conference-paper/1991/10/01/proceedings-14th-national-computer-security-conference-1991/documents/1991-14th-NCSC-proceedings-vol-2.pdf

[2] Chris Salter, O. Sami Saydjari, Bruce Schneier, Jim Wallner, "Toward a secure system engineering methodology," NSPW '98: Proceedings of the 1998 workshop on New security paradigms
https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/310889.310900

I gave Hofstadter's MU puzzle¹ to #ChatGPT to see how quickly its ability to reason fell apart. I hoped this would show something interesting about its robustness at the syntactic level of symbols versus on the semantic level of meaning. I changed "M", "I", and "U" to "A", "B", and "C", respectively, just in case that helped thwart popular training data. The results were disappointing: it failed at the syntactic level, violating string state, puzzle rules, or both.

¹ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MU_puzzle

title: Ahh, Rick Beato Dissected My Theme Tune!!

last_post.content:
It's fun to watch Rick Beato analyze Justin Hawkins' theme tune:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=trjN9_OE8-E

Both of them do a lot of music videos on YouTube - but Beato really knows music theory, Hawkins not so much. So Hawkins is gobsmacked when Beato instantly recognizes that his first chord is a half-diminished seventh. He asks Beato to repeat that phrase, and he asks why it's just *half* diminished. Beato explains, laughing as he does.

But Hawkins does something admirable here.

(1/2)
